solution.text:
Given numbers are :
_{{((7*j)+2)*i}}_ and _{{((3*j)+1)*i}}_
According to Euclid's division lemma:
c = dq + r
Step 1 : Since _{{((7*j)+2)*i}}_ > _{{((3*j)+1)*i}}_,
We apply the division lemma to _{{((7*j)+2)*i}}_ and _{{((3*j)+1)*i}}_
to get:
_{{((7*j)+4)*i}}_ = \(_{{((3*j)+1)*i}}_\times 2\) + _{{j*i}}_
Step 2 : Since the remainder \(_{{j*i}}_\neq 0\)
We apply the division lemma to :
_{{((3*j)+1)*i}}_ and _{{j*i}}_
_{{((3*j)+1)*i}}_ = \(_{{j*i}}_\times 3\) + _{i}_
Step 3 : Applying lemma until remainder becomes zero.
We consider the new divisor _{{j*i}}_ and the new remainder _{i}_, and apply the division lemma to get:
_{{j*i}}_ = \(_{i}_\times _{j}_\) + 0
The remainder has now become zero, so our procedure stops.
Since the divisor at this stage is _{i}_, the HCF of _{{163*i}}_ and _{{21*i}}_ is _{i}_
Therefore, the maximum numbers of columns of fruits are _{i}_.

content.text: A fruit seller has _{{((7*j)+2)*i}}_ mangoes and _{{((3*j)+1)*i}}_ oranges.Fruit seller wants to keep them in same number of columns.Find the maximum numbers of columns in which he can keep mangoes and oranges.
